{{Infobox musical artist | name = A.Y. | image = A.Y. (musician).jpg | landscape = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Ambwene Allen Yessayah | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1981|07|05}} | birth_place = [[Mtwara]], [[Tanzania]] | origin = | death_date = | death_place = | genre = [[Bongo Flava]], [[hip hop music|hip-hop]] | occupation = | instrument = | years_active = 1996-present | label = | associated_acts = S.O.G., East Coast Army, MwanaFA }} '''Ambwene Allen Yessayah''', better known by his stage name as '''A.Y.''', is a Tanzanian [[bongo flava]] artist. He was born on July 5, 1981, in [[Mtwara]], Southern part of [[Tanzania]]. He began his career with the group S.O.G. in 1996. He decided to go solo in 2002. AY is among the first bongo flava artists to commercialize [[hip hop]]. He was member of the musical group known as East Coast Army, but now he's no longer part of the group. He is still releasing songs and albums collaborating most with an ex-coast artist MwanaFA.<ref>{{cite web|title=Most selling local Hip Hop artiste|url=http://www.thisday.co.tz/?l=10587|publisher=This Day|accessdate=8 August 2014|date=25 January 2010}}</ref>
== Discography == *''Raha Kamili'' *''Hisia Zangu'' *"Zigo *Habari Ndiyo Hiyo *Kings & Queens Ft. Amani & Jokate <ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Jxv6dRpbgCI</ref> *Microphone Ft. Fid Q <ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fwAz5duP5z8</ref> *More & More Ft. Nyashinski <ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4ZDeh6PjPCQ</ref> *Touch Me Touch Me Ft. Sean Kingstone & Mis Trinity <ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mvpt3LfrykE</ref> *Yule <ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1STunAVrsOU</ref> *Zigo Remix Ft. Diamond Platnumz <ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oZS3fekWNOM</ref>
== Awards ==
=== Won === *2007 [[Tanzania Music Awards]] - Best Hip Hop Single ('Usijaribu')<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kilitime.co.tz/awards/2007/winners/index.html |title=Tanzania Music Awards - Winner 2007 |publisher=Kilitime.co.tz |date= |accessdate=2010-09-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100710192951/http://kilitime.co.tz/awards/2007/winners/index.html |archivedate=2010-07-10 |df= }}</ref> *[[2007 Kisima Music Awards]] - Best Video From Tanzania ('Usijaribu')<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kisimaawards.co.ke/kminner.asp?cat=winners07 |title=Kisima Awards winners 2007 |publisher=Kisimaawards.co.ke |date=2007-07-17 |accessdate=2010-09-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722132158/http://www.kisimaawards.co.ke/kminner.asp?cat=winners07 |archivedate=2011-07-22 |df= }}</ref> *2008 [[Tanzania Music Awards]] - Collaboration of the Year ("Habari Ndio Hiyo"), with [[Mwanafalsafa]]<ref>[http://www.kilitimetz.com/awards/2008/winners/index.html Tanzania Music Awards - Winner 2008]</ref> *2008 [[Pearl of Africa Music Awards]] - Best Tanzanian Male Artist<ref>Museke: [http://museke.com/en/node/2396 PAM Awards Winners 2008] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090418144712/http://museke.com/en/node/2396 |date=2009-04-18 }}</ref> *[[2010 Tanzania music awards]] - Best Reggae Song ('Leo (Reggae remix)' with [[Avril (singer)|Avril]])<ref>The Citizen: [https://archive.is/20130113220550/http://www.thecitizen.co.tz/sunday-citizen/40-sunday-citizen-news/1958-diamond-becomes-toast-of-kili-awards-night.html Diamond becomes toast of Kili Awards night]. Archived from [http://www.thecitizen.co.tz/sunday-citizen/40-sunday-citizen-news/1958-diamond-becomes-toast-of-kili-awards-night.html the original] on 15 May 2010. Retrieved 17 July 2017.</ref> *[[2012 Channel O Music Video Awards]] - Best East African Video
=== Nominations === *2005 [[Kora Awards]] - Best East African Male Artist<ref>Kora Awards: [https://web.archive.org/web/20061113084534/http://www.koraawards.co.za/english/musicawards_finalists.asp Kora Awards 2005 nominees]</ref> *2008 [[Kisima Music Awards]] - Tanzanian Video of the Year ("Nangoja Ageuke", with [[Mwanafalsafa]]) & East African Collaboration of the Year ("Usiwe Mbali", with [[Amani (musician)|Amani]])<ref>Kisima Awards: [https://archive.is/20081014030208/http://www.kisimaawards.co.ke/kminner.asp?cat=nom08&pcat=nominees Nominees 2008]</ref> *[[MTV Africa Music Awards 2009|2009 MTV Africa Music Awards]] - Best Hip Hop<ref>Museke: [http://www.museke.com/en/node/3989 MTV Africa Music Awards (MAMAs) 2009 nominees]</ref> *2009 [[Channel O Music Video Awards]] - Best African East ("Naongea Na Wewe" with [[Mwanafalsafa]])<ref name="n3780">Museke: [http://museke.com/en/node/3780 2009 Channel O Africa Music Video Awards nominees]</ref> *[[2010 Tanzania music awards]] - Best Music Video ('Leo') *[[2011 Tanzania Music Awards]] - Best Male Artist, Best Hip Hop Song ('Usije Mjini' with Mwana FA), Best Collaboration Song ('Dakika Moja' with FA & Hardmad), Best East African Song ('Songa Mbele' with Alpha)<ref>allAfrica.com: [http://allafrica.com/stories/201102220178.html '20 Percent' Grabs Seven Kili Music Awards Nominations]</ref> *[[2012 Tanzania Music Awards]] - Best Ragga/Dancehall Song ('Good look' with Ms. Triniti) * 2012 Channel O Music Video Awards - Video of the Year (featuring [[Romeo Miller|Romeo]] and [[La'Myia Good|Lamyia]] - Speak With Your Body)

{{Infobox spaceflight | name = ACRIMSAT | image = ACRIMSat (transparent).png | image_caption = ACRIMSAT | insignia =
| mission_type = Solar astronomy | operator = [[National Aeronautics and Space Administration|NASA]]{{\}}[[Jet Propulsion Laboratory|JPL]] | website = {{url|http://acrim.jpl.nasa.gov/}} | COSPAR_ID = 1999-070B | SATCAT = 26033 | mission_duration = 7 years
| manufacturer = [[Orbital Sciences Corporation|Orbital Sciences]] | launch_mass = {{convert|288|kg}} | dimensions = | power = 80.0 watts
| launch_date = {{start-date|21 December 1999, 07:13|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = [[Taurus (rocket)|Taurus 2110]] | launch_site = [[Vandenberg Air Force Base|Vandenberg]] [[Vandenberg AFB Launch Complex 576|LC-576E]] | launch_contractor = [[Orbital Sciences Corporation|Orbital Sciences]]
| disposal_type = | deactivated = | last_contact = 14 December 2013 | decay_date =
| orbit_epoch = 5 December 2013, 12:18:57 UTC<ref name="n2yo">{{cite web|url=http://www.n2yo.com/satellite/?s=26033|title=ACRIMSAT Satellite details 1999-070B NORAD 26033|work=N2YO|date=5 December 2013|accessdate=6 December 2013}}</ref> | orbit_reference = [[Geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Sun-synchronous orbit|Sun-synchronous]] | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|675|km|mi|abbr=on}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|717|km|mi|abbr=on}} | orbit_inclination = 97.80 degrees | orbit_semimajor = {{convert|7067.28|km|mi|abbr=on}} | orbit_eccentricity = 0.0029721 | orbit_period = 98.54 minutes | apsis = gee
| telescope_name = <!--name, if different to the satellite--> | telescope_type = <!--type of telescope, mirror arrangement, etc--> | telescope_diameter = <!--diameter of telescope--> | telescope_focal_length= <!--focal length of telescope--> | telescope_area = <!--collecting area--> | telescope_wavelength = <!--wavelengths at which the telescope operates--> }}
The '''Active Cavity Radiometer Irradiance Monitor Satellite''', or '''ACRIMSAT''' is a defunct satellite and instrument that was one of the 21 observational components of [[NASA]]'s [[Earth Observing System]] program. The instrument followed upon the ACRIM1 and ACRIM2 instruments that were also launched on multi-instrument satellite platforms. ACRIMSAT was launched on 20 December 1999 from [[Vandenberg Air Force Base]] as the secondary payload on the [[Taurus rocket]] that launched [[KOMPSAT]]. It was placed into a high inclination, 700 km. [[sun-synchronous orbit]] from which the ACRIM3 instrument monitored total solar irradiance (TSI).<ref>[http://acrim.com/TSI%20Monitoring.htm Composite TSI Time Series]</ref> Contact with the satellite was lost on 14 December 2013.<ref name="JPL">[http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=4252 "Sun sets for a NASA solar monitoring spacecraft."] ''Jet Propulsion Laboratory.'' Retrieved: 9 August 2015.</ref>
== History == ACRIM3 made measurements of the [[Solar irradiance|TSI]] since the start of its mission in April 2000. It extended the TSI measurement database begun by earlier ACRIM instruments on the NASA [[Solar Maximum Mission]] (ACRIM1: 1980–1989) and [[Upper Atmosphere Research Satellite]] (ACRIM2: 1991–2001).<ref>[https://eospso.nasa.gov/missions/active-cavity-radiometer-irradiance-monitor-satellite "Active Cavity Radiometer Irradiance Monitor Satellite (ACRIMSAT)."] ''NASA's Earth Observing System.'' Retrieved: 12 March 2018.</ref>
ACRIMSAT/ACRIM3 tracked TSI during a 2004 [[transit of Venus]] and measured the 0.1% reduction in the solar intensity caused by the planet's shadow.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/cgi-bin/resolve?doi=10.1086/500427.html |journal=The Astrophysical Journal |issue=641 |pp=565–571 |date=2006 |last1=Schneider |first1=G. |first2=J. M. |last2=Pasachoff |first3=Richard C. |last3=Willson |title=The Effect of the Transit of Venus on ACRIM's Total Solar Irradiance Measurements: Implications for Transit Studies of Extrasolar Planets |doi=10.1086/500427|arxiv=astro-ph/0512251 |bibcode=2006ApJ...641..565S }}</ref> It also recorded data for the [[Transit of Venus, 2012|2012 Transit of Venus]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://photojournal.jpl.nasa.gov/catalog/PIA15820|title=Catalog Page for PIA15820|work=nasa.gov}}</ref>
On 14 December 2013, ACRIMSAT went silent, with attempts to reestablish contact proving unsuccessful. The mostly likely cause has been attributed to the failure of aging batteries. The defunct spacecraft will remain in orbit for approximately 64 years before returning to Earth.<ref name="JPL"/>
== Team == Richard C. Willson was the principal investigator and led the science team.<ref>{{Cite web|title = ACRIM Staff Information|url = http://acrim.com/staff.htm|website = acrim.com|accessdate = 2015-07-25}}</ref> Willson designed the [[active cavity radiometer]] type of sensor used by self-calibrating satellite TSI monitoring experiments. The ACRIM3 instrument was a collaboration between Willson, original JPL/ACRIMSAT Project Manager Ronald Zenone and ACRIM3 Instrument Scientist Roger Helizon. The Mission was controlled using the ACRIMSAT tracking station at the [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory|Jet Propulsion Labs]] (JPL) Table Mountain Observatory in Southern California. Co-Investigators were: [[Nicola Scafetta]] (climate impact of solar variability), Hugh Hudson (solar physics)and Alexander Mordvinov (solar physics).
== Technology == ACRIMSAT was a spin-stabilized, single-purpose satellite constructed by [[Orbital Sciences Corporation]]. Its total cost, including the instrument, launch, ground station, operations and science team activities during its 14-year mission was less than $50 million.
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{Portal|Spaceflight}} * [http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/press_kits/acrimsat.pdf AcrimSat Launch] * [http://www.acrim.com ACRIM Science Team homepage] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070428034331/http://acrim.jpl.nasa.gov/ ACRIMSAT Project homepage] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080409115941/http://eospso.gsfc.nasa.gov/eos_homepage/mission_profiles/docs/ACRIMSAT.pdf Fact sheet on the mission] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20091007202402/http://nasascience.nasa.gov/missions/acrimsat/ ACRIMSAT: NASA Science Missions]

revision.comment: Changing [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]] from "a type of volcanic rock" to "A class of intermediate to felsic volcanic rocks containing low amounts of yttrium and ytterbium" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|A class of intermediate to felsic volcanic rocks containing low amounts of yttrium and ytterbium}} [[File:Locomóviles y el Mackay.JPG|thumb|Cerro Mackay, a mountain in [[Coyhaique]] in Chile, made of [[Columnar jointing|columns]] of adakite<ref name="CerroMackay1">{{cite web | url=http://planet-terre.ens-lyon.fr/image-de-la-semaine/Img584-2017-11-13.xml | title=Les adakites de Coyhaique (Chili) : des prismes extraordinaires faits de roches rares dans un contexte géologique peu fréquent | publisher=[[École normale supérieure de Lyon|ENS de Lyon]] | work=Planet Terre | date=13 November 2017 | accessdate=18 May 2018 | author=Thomas, Pierre | language=French }}</ref>]] '''Adakites''' are [[volcanic rock]]s of [[Intermediate composition|intermediate]] to [[felsic]] composition that have [[Geochemistry|geochemical]] characteristics of [[magma]] thought to have formed by [[partial melting]] of altered [[basalt]] that is [[Subduction|subducted]] below [[volcanic arc]]s.<ref name="Defant">{{cite journal | url=http://www.geo.mtu.edu/EHaz/ConvergentPlatesClass/macpherson/defand_drummond_1990.pdf | title=Derivation of some modern arc magmas by melting of young subducted lithosphere |author1=Defant M.J. |author2=Drummond M.S. | journal=Nature | year=1990 | volume=347 | pages=662–665 | doi=10.1038/347662a0}}</ref>{{dubious|date=August 2018}} Most magmas derived in subduction zones come from the [[Mantle (geology)|mantle]] above the subducting plate when hydrous fluids are released from minerals that break down in the [[metamorphism|metamorphosed]] basalt, rise into the mantle, and initiate partial melting. However, Defant and Drummond recognized that when young [[oceanic crust]] (less than 25 million years old) is subducted, adakites are typically produced in the arc. They postulated that when young oceanic crust is subducted it is "warmer" (closer to the [[mid-ocean ridge]] where it formed) than crust that is typically subducted. The warmer crust enables melting of the metamorphosed subducted basalt rather than the mantle above. Experimental work by several researchers has verified the geochemical characteristics of "slab melts" and the contention that melts can form from young and therefore warmer crust in subduction zones.<ref name="Rapp">{{cite journal | url=http://petrology.oxfordjournals.org/content/36/4/891.short | title=Dehydration Melting of Metabasalt at 8–32 kbar: Implications for Continental Growth and Crust-Mantle Recycling |author1=Rapp R.P. |author2=Watson E.B. | journal=Journal of Petrology | year=1995 | volume=36 | issue=4 | pages=891–931 | doi=10.1093/petrology/36.4.891}}</ref>
The [[Geochemistry|geochemical]] characteristics Defant and Drummond gave for adakites are: *[[Silica|SiO<sub>2</sub>]] greater than 56 wt % *[[Alumina|Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>]] greater than or equal to 15 wt % *[[Magnesium oxide|MgO]] normally less than 3 wt % *[[Strontium|Sr]] greater than 400 [[Parts per million|ppm]] *[[Yttrium|Y]] less than 18 ppm *[[Ytterbium|Yb]] less than 1.9 ppm *[[Isotopes of strontium|<sup>87</sup>Sr/<sup>86</sup>Sr]] usually less than 0.7045
Later Defant and Kepezhinskas reviewed the topic in some detail pointing out that adakites are found associated with many [[mineral deposit]]s including [[gold]] and [[copper]].<ref name="Defant_2001">{{cite journal | url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/01EO00038/abstract | title=Evidence suggests slab melting in arc magmas |author1=Defant M.J. |author2=Kepezhinskas P. | journal=Eos | year=2001 | volume=82 | issue=6 | pages=65–69 | doi=10.1029/01EO00038}}</ref>
Drummond and Defant noted that [[Archean]] [[trondhjemite]]s (which make up most of the ancient crust of continents) have similar geochemical characteristics to adakites.<ref name="Drummond">{{cite journal | url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/JB095iB13p21503/abstract | title=A model for Trondhjemite-Tonalite-Dacite Genesis and crustal growth via slab melting: Archean to modern comparisons |author1=Drummond M.S. |author2=Defant M.J. | journal=Journal of Geophysical Research: Solid Earth | year=1990 | volume=95 | issue=B13 | pages=21503–21521 | doi=10.1029/JB095iB13p21503}}</ref> They suggested that the entire Archean crust may have been derived from the partial melting of subducted oceanic crust during the Archean (> 2.5 billion years ago) because during early earth the temperature of the mantle was much hotter and more oceanic crust was generated and subducted younger. The proposal has been controversial and is still being argued among the scientific community. The alternative interpretation is that the [[continental crust]] was derived from the partial melting of lower crustal basalts. The same idea has also been postulated for the generation of adakites. However, this hypothesis does not explain the correlation between subducted young crust and adakite eruptions nor the fact that the lower Yb and Y in adakites suggest that [[garnet]] is stable in the source. Garnet forms only under high pressures within the earth and would not be stable in lower crust below some island arcs that erupt adakites. See Martin et al. for a more recent summary.<ref name="Martin">{{cite journal | url=http://www.geo.mtu.edu/EHaz/ConvergentPlatesClass/macpherson/martin_etal_2005.pdf | title=An overview of adakite, tonalite–trondhjemite–granodiorite (TTG), and sanukitoid: relationships and some implications for crustal evolution |author1=Martin H. |author2=Smithies R.H. |author3=Rapp R. |author4=Moyen J.-F. |author5=Champion D. | journal= [[Lithos (journal)|Lithos]] | year=2005 | volume=79 | pages=1–24 | doi=10.1016/j.lithos.2004.04.048}}</ref>
Low [[magnesium]] adakites may be representative of relatively pure partial melting of a subducting basalt, whereas high magnesium adakite or high magnesium [[andesite]]s may represent melt contamination with the [[peridotite]]s of the overlying [[mantle wedge]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.the-conference.com/JConfAbs/1/497.html |title=R. P. Rapp and N. Shimizu, ''Arc Magmatism in Hot Subduction Zones: Interactions Between Slab-Derived Melts and the Mantle Wedge, and the Petrogenesis of Adakites and High-Magnesian Andesites (HMA)'' Conference abstract |access-date=2007-09-24 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060514160253/http://www.the-conference.com/JConfAbs/1/497.html |archive-date=2006-05-14 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> Adakites have also been reported from the continent-continent collision zone beneath [[Tibet]].<ref>[http://geology.gsapubs.org/content/31/11/1021.abstract Chung, Sun-Lin, et al. ''Adakites from continental collision zones: Melting of thickened lower crust beneath southern Tibet,'' Geology v. 31 no. 11 p. 1021-1024]</ref>
==Examples== * [[Adak Island]], Alaska * [[Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt]], Mexico * [[Mindanao]], the Philippines<ref name="SajonaEtAl1994">{{cite journal | url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0040195194901589 | title=Magmatic response to abrupt changes in geodynamic settings: Pliocene—Quaternary calc-alkaline and Nb-enriched lavas from Mindanao (Philippines) | first=F.G. | last=Sajona | first2=H. | last2=Bellon | first3=R.C. | last3=Maury | first4=M. | last4=Pubellier | first5=J. | last5=Cotten | first6=C. | last6=Rangin | journal=Tectonophysics | year=1994 | volume=237 | pages=47–72 | doi=10.1016/0040-1951(94)90158-9}}</ref>
==References== <references/>

revision.text:
{{About|the air pollution index used in Canada|air pollution indices in general|Air quality index}} :'' For the Air Quality Health Index issued by Hong Kong's Environmental Protection Department, see [[Air Quality Health Index (Hong Kong)]].'' {{Infobox organization | formation = 2005 | headquarters = [[Ottawa]], [[Ontario]], Canada | leader_title = [[Minister of the Environment (Canada)|Minister of the Environment]] | leader_name = [[Catherine McKenna]] | name = Air Quality Health Index
{{lang|fr|La Cote air santé}} | chief1_position = Chief Executive Officer | website = http://www.airhealth.ca http://www.coteairsante.ca }} The '''Air Quality Health Index''' or ('''AQHI''') is a scale designed in [[Canada]] to help understand the impact of [[air quality]] on health. It is a health protection tool used to make decisions to reduce short-term exposure to air pollution by adjusting activity levels during increased levels of air pollution. The Air Quality Health Index also provides advice on how to improve air quality by proposing behavioral change to reduce the [[environmental footprint]]. This index pays particular attention to people who are sensitive to air pollution. It provides them with advice on how to protect their health during air quality levels associated with low, moderate, high and very high health risks.{{cite web|url=http://www.ec.gc.ca/cas-aqhi/default.asp?lang=En&n=065BE995-1 |title=Environment Canada - Air - About the Air Quality Health Index |publisher=Ec.gc.ca |date=2013-07-16 |accessdate=2013-07-23}} ==History== Air quality in [[Canada]] has been historically been reported by the [[Air quality index#United States|USA's Air Quality Index]] in various provinces. Significantly, AQI values reflect air quality management objectives, which are based on the lowest achievable emissions rate, and not exclusively concern for human health. The AQHI was created with a different goal - to report on the specific health risks posed by air pollution. As such, the AQHI represents a paradigm shift in communicating air quality information to the public. The Air Quality Health Index or "AQHI" is a federal program jointly coordinated by [[Health Canada]] and [[Environment Canada]]. However, the AQHI program would not be possible without the commitment and support of the provinces, municipalities and NGOs. From air quality monitoring to health risk communication and community engagement, local partners are responsible for the vast majority of work related to AQHI implementation. The AQHI has been rolled out across Canada and has replaced the AQI as the public face of air quality information. Originally launched as a pilot project in the [[British Columbia Interior]] and [[Nova Scotia]] in 2005, it is currently implemented in 103 communities across Canada.{{cite web|url=http://www.ec.gc.ca/cas-aqhi/default.asp?lang=En&n=450C1129-1 |title=Environment Canada - Air - National Map |publisher=Ec.gc.ca |date=2016-06-08 |accessdate=2017-03-17}} ==Overview== The ''Air Quality Health Index'' provides a number from 1 to 10+ to indicate the level of health risk associated with local air quality. Occasionally, when the amount of air pollution is abnormally high, the number may exceed 10. The AQHI provides a local air quality current value as well as a local air quality maximums forecast for today, tonight and tomorrow and provides associated health advice. {| style="margin:auto; background:Black; color:White; font-size:larger;" |- style="text-align:center;" | style="width:35px; height:35px; background:#0cf;"| '''1''' || style="text-align:center; width:35px; height:35px; background:#09c;"| '''2''' || style="text-align:center; width:35px; height:35px; background:#069;"| '''3''' || style="text-align:center; width:35px; height:35px; background:yellow; color:black;"| '''4''' || style="height:35px; height:35px; text-align:center; width:35px; text-align:center; width:35px; background:#fc0; color:black;"| '''5''' || style="text-align:center; width:35px; height:35px; background:#f93;"| '''6''' || style="text-align:center; width:35px; height:35px; background:#f66;"| '''7''' || style="text-align:center; width:35px; height:35px; background:red;"| '''8''' || style="width:18px; width:35px; text-align:center; text-align:center; height:35px; background:#c00;"| '''9'''|| style="width:18px; width:35px; text-align:center; text-align:center; height:35px; background:#900;"| '''10''' || style="text-align:center; width:35px; height:35px; background:#600;"| '''+''' |} {| style="margin:auto; background:white; color:black;" |- ||'''Risk:'''|| Low '''(1-3)'''|| Moderate '''(4-6)'''|| High '''(7-10)''' || Very high '''(above 10)''' |} As it is now known that even low levels of air pollution can trigger discomfort for the sensitive population, the index has been developed as a continuum: The higher the number, the greater the health risk and need to take precautions. The index describes the level of health risk associated with this number as ‘low’, ‘moderate’, ‘high’ or ‘very high’, and suggests steps that can be taken to reduce exposure. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Health Risk !! Air Quality Health Index !! '''Health Messages for At-Risk Population''' !! '''Health messages for General Population''' |- | '''Low''' || '''1-3'''|| '''Enjoy''' your usual outdoor activities.||'''Ideal''' air quality for outdoor activities |- | '''Moderate''' || '''4-6''' || '''Consider reducing''' or rescheduling strenuous activities outdoors if you are experiencing symptoms.||'''No need to modify''' your usual outdoor activities unless you experience symptoms such as coughing and throat irritation. |- | '''High''' || '''7-10''' || '''Reduce''' or reschedule strenuous activities outdoors. Children and the elderly should also take it easy.||'''Consider reducing''' or rescheduling strenuous activities outdoors if you experience symptoms such as coughing and throat irritation. |- | '''Very high''' || '''Above 10''' || '''Avoid''' strenuous activities outdoors. Children and the elderly should also avoid outdoor physical exertion.||'''Reduce''' or reschedule strenuous activities outdoors, especially if you experience symptoms such as coughing and throat irritation. |}{{cite web|url=http://www.ec.gc.ca/cas-aqhi/default.asp?lang=En&n=79A8041B-1 |title=Environment Canada - Air - AQHI categories and explanations |publisher=Ec.gc.ca |date=2013-07-16 |accessdate=2013-07-23}} ==Formula inputs== The formulation of the national AQHI is based on the observed relationship of [[nitrogen dioxide]] (NO2), ground-level [[ozone]] (O3) and [[Atmospheric particulate matter|fine particulate matter]] (PM2.5) with mortality from an analysis of several Canadian cities. Significantly, all three of these pollutants can pose health risks, even at low levels of exposure, especially among those with pre-existing health problems.{{cite journal|title= A new multipollutant, no-threshold air quality health index based on short-term associations observed in daily time-series analyses|date=2013-03-25 |pmid=18376646 | volume=58 |journal=J Air Waste Manag Assoc |pages=435–50 | last1 = Stieb | first1 = DM | last2 = Burnett | first2 = RT | last3 = Smith-Doiron | first3 = M | last4 = Brion | first4 = O | last5 = Shin | first5 = HH | last6 = Economou | first6 = V}} When developing the AQHI, Health Canada’s original analysis of health effects included five major air pollutants: airborne particulate matter, ozone, and nitrogen dioxide (NO2), as well as [[sulphur dioxide]] (SO2), and [[carbon monoxide]] (CO). The latter two pollutants provided little information in predicting health effects and were removed from the AQHI formulation. The AQHI does not measure the effects of odour, [[pollen]], dust, heat or humidity. ==Calculation== The national AQHI is based on three-hour average concentrations of ground-level ozone (O3), nitrogen dioxide (NO2), and fine particulate matter (PM2.5). O3 and NO2 are measured in parts per billion (ppb) while PM2.5 is measured in micrograms per cubic metre (ug/m3). The AQHI is calculated on a community basis (each community may have one or more monitoring stations). First, the average concentration of the 3 substances (O3, NO2, PM2.5) is calculated at each station within a community for the 3 preceding hours. This is considered valid only if at least 2 out of 3 hours are available at the station. If more than 1 of the preceding 3 hours is missing the station average is set to "Not Available". This part of the process results in three "station parameter averages" for each station. Second, the 3 hour "community average" for each parameter is calculated from the 3 hour substance averages at the available stations. If no stations are available for a parameter, that parameter is set to "Not Available". This part of the process results in 3 community parameter averages. Third, if all three community parameter averages are available, a community AQHI is calculated. The formula is: AQHI=(\frac{1000}{10.4})\times[(e^{0.000537\times O_3}-1)+(e^{0.000871\times NO_2}-1)+(e^{0.000487\times PM_{2.5}}-1)]{{Cite journal|last=Stieb|first=David M.|last2=Burnett|first2=Richard T.|last3=Smith-Doiron|first3=Marc|last4=Brion|first4=Orly|last5=Shin|first5=Hwashin Hyun|last6=Economou|first6=Vanita|date=24 Jan 2012|title=A New Multipollutant, No-Threshold Air Quality Health Index Based on Short-Term Associations Observed in Daily Time-Series Analyses|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.3155/1047-3289.58.3.435|journal=Journal of the Air & Waste Management Association|volume=58|pages=435–450|via=}} The result is then rounded to the nearest positive integer; a calculation less than 0.5 is rounded up to 1. ==Alberta calculation and reporting differences== [[Alberta]] has modified AQHI reporting to better suit the needs of the Province. Because of Alberta's energy based economy other pollutants are also considered when reporting the AQHI. Alberta also has rapidly changing air quality conditions quite often (for example during wildfire season) so, Alberta’s AQHI needs to be more responsive than the national AQHI, which is based on a three-hour average. In order to meet these needs, the individual pollutant concentrations are compared to Alberta’s Ambient Air Quality Objectives (AAQOs). The national AQHI is used most of the time; however, if hourly air pollutant concentrations are higher than Alberta’s AAQOs, the AQHI value is replaced (overridden) with the appropriate “High” or “Very High” risk value. This can occur for the following pollutants (when they exceed the noted concentrations): * 80 micrograms per cubic metre for fine particulate matter * 82 parts per billion for ozone * 159 parts per billion for nitrogen dioxide * 172 parts per billion for sulphur dioxide * 13 parts per million for carbon monoxide * 1 part per million for hydrogen sulphide and total reduced sulphur{{cite web|url=http://environment.alberta.ca/03603.html |title=How is AQHI Reporting Enhanced in Alberta? – Alberta Environment and Sustainable Resource Development |publisher=Environment.alberta.ca |date=2011-06-14 |accessdate=2013-07-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130925202706/http://environment.alberta.ca/03603.html |archivedate=2013-09-25 }} In Alberta, special community messaging is used when the level of specific pollutants is higher than specified odour or visibility thresholds but the AQHI is rated as “Low” or “Moderate” risk. This messaging is used for the following pollutants (when they exceed the noted concentrations): * 25 micrograms per cubic metre for fine particulate matter (based on visibility) * 100 parts per billion for sulphur dioxide (based on odour) * 10 parts per billion for hydrogen sulphide or total reduced sulphur (based on odour) This odour/visibility messaging appears as below: Alberta has developed its own AQHI website at http://airquality.alberta.ca. ==Persons at risk== The ''AQHI'' is aimed towards two populations: 1. The “general” population; and 2. The “at-risk” populations. The later consists of children, the elderly and people with existing respiratory or cardiovascular conditions, such as those with [[asthma]], and people suffering from [[diabetes]], [[heart disease]] or [[lung disease]]. Children are more vulnerable to air pollution: they have less-developed respiratory and defense systems. Because of their size, they inhale more air per kilogram of body weight than adults. Their elevated metabolic rate and young defense systems make them more susceptible to air pollution. Seniors are also at a higher risk because of the weakening of the heart, lungs and immune system and increased likelihood of health problems such as heart and lung disease. Exposure to air pollutants can cause a range of symptoms. People with lung or heart disease may experience increased frequency and/or severity of symptoms, and increased medication requirements. It is recommended that those susceptive should take greater precautions.{{cite web|url=http://www.ec.gc.ca/cas-aqhi/default.asp?lang=En&n=8727DF6F-1 |title=Environment Canada - Air - Are you at risk? |publisher=Ec.gc.ca |date=2013-07-16 |accessdate=2013-07-23}} ==Lifestyle== [[Environment Canada]] recommends looking for outdoor air quality by checking the ''AQHI'' in your community before heading off to work or play as well as to use the forecasts to plan activities, whether over the next hour or the next day. Seniors, parents, those with asthma, and people suffering from diabetes, heart or lung disease, can use the ''AQHI'' to assess the immediate risk air pollution poses on their health and take steps to lessen that risk. The ''AQHI'' is also recommended for healthy, fit and active people to consult to decide when it is best to exercise or work outdoor. The best way for someone to use the ''AQHI'' is to regularly check the current index value, to pay attention to personal symptoms and self-calibrate to the reported current ''AQHI'' value. For example, if symptoms are experienced when the index is a 6, then precaution should be taken when the index is at a 6 or higher by following the corresponding health messages. Then, when an individual knows what number triggers health symptoms, to get in the habit of checking the maximum forecast to plan activities ahead of time. The ''AQHI'' is easily accessible via the web: At http://www.airhealth.ca and http://www.weatheroffice.gc.ca/canada_e.html. The AQHI is also available for download as a desktop widget for Windows and Mac, and iPhone app, http://mirtchovski.com/code/AQHI.html. There are several news feeds and blogs dedicated to the AQHI: http://www.ec.gc.ca/cas-aqhi/default.asp?lang=En&n=C7B2359F-1. == See also == *[[National Ambient Air Quality Objectives]] for Canada ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.airhealth.ca Air Quality Health Index], Government of Canada *{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121227094216/http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/ewh-semt/air/out-ext/effe/health_effects-effets_sante-eng.php|title=Health Effects of Air Pollution|last=|first=|date=2012-12-27|website=Health Canada|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-18}} * [http://www.toronto.ca/health/airquality/aqhi/index.htm ''AQHI Available in 13 Languages''] * [http://mirtchovski.com/code/AQHI.html ''Flash AQHI Widget''] *{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130410115028/http://www.theweathernetwork.com/airquality/whatis|title=Air Quality: What is AQHI?|last=|first=|date=2013-04-10|website=The Weather Network|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-18}} * [http://airquality.alberta.ca ''Alberta Air Quality Health Index''] * [http://picasaweb.google.com/lh/sredir?uname=thecleanairpartnership&target=ALBUM&id=5356080206208401857&authkey=Gv1sRgCNX_1c-16vqRgQE&feat=email AQHI video]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110503213220/http://www.greennexxus.com/gnx.aspx?name=AA-home Be Air Aware] Twitter *{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/environmentca|title=Environment Canada (@environmentca)|last=|first=|date=|website=Twitter|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-18}} *{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/environnementca|title=Environnement Canada (@environnementca)|last=|first=|date=|website=Twitter|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-18}} {{Natural resources}} [[Category:Air pollution]] [[Category:Air quality index]]

A '''bevameter''' is a device used in [[terramechanics]] to measure the mechanical properties of [[soil]].Bevameter technique was developed to measure terrain mechanical properties for the study of vehicle mobility  Bevameter test consists of penetration test to measure normal loads and shear test to determine shear loads exerted by vehicle.  Bevameter area size need to be the size of the wheel or track. DEM analysis can take data from one size and simulate bevameter performance for a different size.
==External links== *[http://www-personal.umich.edu/~johannb/Papers/paper111.pdf Terrain Trafficability Characterization with a Mobile Robot], Ojeda, L., Borenstein, J., Witus, G.
[[Category:Soil science]] [[Category:Measuring instruments]]
{{tool-stub}}

page.title: Eastern savannas of the United States

revision.comment: Rescued 1 archive link; remove 1 link. [[User:GreenC/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text:
The '''eastern savannas of the United States''' covered large portions of the southeast side of the continent until the early 20th century. These were in a [[fire ecology]] of open grassland and forests with low ground cover of herbs and grasses. [[File:Grand Bay NOAA Nerr0754.jpg|thumb|Maritime slash pine savanna]]
The frequent fires which maintained the [[savanna]]s were started by the region's many [[thunderstorm]]s and [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]]s, with most fires burning the forest understory and not affecting the mature trees above. Before the arrival of humans about 15,000 years ago, [[lightning]] would have been the major source of ignition, the region having the most frequent wind and lightning storms in North America.<ref name="Brown2000">{{cite web|url=http://www.treesearch.fs.fed.us/pubs/4554|title=Wildland fire in ecosystems: effects of fire on flora|last=Brown|first=James K.|author2=Smith, Jane Kapler|year=2000|work=Gen. Tech. Rep. RMRS-GTR-42-vol. 2|publisher=Department of Agriculture, Forest Service, Rocky Mountain Research Station|pages=56–68|accessdate=2008-07-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Earley|first=Lawrence S.|title=Looking for Longleaf: The Fall And Rise of an American Forest|publisher=UNC Press|year=2006|isbn=0-8078-5699-1}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.srs.fs.fed.us/sustain/report/fire/fire-06.htm|title=Use of Fire by Native Americans|work=The Southern Forest Resource Assessment Summary Report|publisher=Southern Research Station, USDA Forest Service|accessdate=2008-07-21}}</ref><ref name="Williams2003">{{cite web|url=http://www.blm.gov/heritage/docum/Fire/Bibliography%20-%20Indian%20Use%20of%20Fire.pdf |title=REFERENCES ON THE AMERICAN INDIAN USE OF FIRE IN ECOSYSTEMS |last=Williams |first=Gerald W. |date=2003-06-12 |accessdate=2008-07-31 |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080706160607/http://www.blm.gov/heritage/docum/Fire/Bibliography%20-%20Indian%20Use%20of%20Fire.pdf |archivedate=2008-07-06 |df= }}</ref> The European settlers who displaced the natives blended the local use of fire with their customary use of fire as pastoral herdsmen in the [[British Isles]], Spain, and France.<ref name=Brown2000 />
In the southern pine savanna, each area burned about every 1–4 years; after settlers arrived burning happened about every 1–3 years. In [[oak]]–[[hickory]] areas, estimates range from 3 to 14 years, although trails were kept open with fire.<ref name=Brown2000 /> [[File:Wildland Fire in Ecosystems 15-1-2.png|thumb|400px|Hypothesized natural fire regimes of United States plants. Savannas have regimes of a few years: blue, pink, and light green areas.]]
== Prehistoric southeastern flora == Of all the United States, southeastern flora has been least changed in composition during the last 20,000 years. During the [[Last Glacial Maximum]] about 18,000 years ago, when the glacial front extended south to the approximate location of the [[Ohio River]], preexisting natural communities in the Southeast remained largely intact. As a result, the Southeast contains a high level of endemism and genetic diversity as would be expected of an old flora.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Predicting Pleistocene climate from vegetation in North America |journal= Climate of the Past |volume=3 |issue=1 |pages=109-118 |url=http://www.clim-past.net/3/109/2007/cp-3-109-2007.pdf |first1=C. |last1=Loehle |date=2007}}</ref> [[Temperate deciduous forest]]s dominated from about 33° to 30° N. latitude, including most of the glacial Gulf Coast from about 84° W. longitude. The coastline later changed during glacial melt, both in the Mississippi River valley and [[sea level rise]] of {{Convert|130|meters|}}. Regional climate was similar to or slightly drier than modern conditions. Oak, hickory, [[American chestnut|chestnut]], and southern pine species were abundant. [[Walnut]]s, [[Fagus grandifolia|beech]], [[Liquidambar styraciflua|sweetgum]], [[alder]], [[birch]], [[Liriodendron tulipifera|tulip tree]], [[elm]]s, [[hornbeam]]s, [[tilia]]s, and others that are generally common in modern southern deciduous forests were also common then. [[Poaceae|Grass]]es, [[Cyperaceae|sedge]]s, and [[Asteraceae|sunflower]]s were also common. Extensive [[Mesophyte|mesophytic]] forest communities, similar to modern lowland and bottomland forests, occurred along major river drainages, especially the Mississippi embayment, the Alabama-Coosa-Tallapoosa Basin, the Apalachicola-Chattahoochee-Flint Basin, and the [[Savannah River]] Basin.<ref name="Owen2002">{{cite web|url=http://www.srs.fs.usda.gov/sustain/report/terra2/terra2.htm|title=Chapter 2 (TERRA–2): The History of Native Plant Communities in the South|last=Owen|first=Wayne|year=2002|work=Southern Forest Resource Assessment Final Report|publisher=U.S. Department of Agriculture, Forest Service, Southern Research Station|accessdate=2008-07-29}}</ref>
Humans arrived as five thousand years passed following the retreat of the glaciers, while deciduous forests expanded northward throughout the region. Pockets of boreal elements remained only at high elevations in the [[Appalachian Mountains]] and in a few other refuges. Broadleaf evergreen and pine forests occupied an extent similar to their current one, primarily in the [[Atlantic coastal plain|Atlantic Coastal Plain]]. Mesophytic and bottomland forest communities continued to occupy the major river drainages of the region.<ref name=Owen2002 />
Although the major modern community types were flourishing in the Southeast by 10,000 years BP, and the climate was similar to that today, the understory flora had not yet come to resemble modern herbaceous floras. Mixed hardwood forests dominated the majority of the upper Coastal Plains, [[Piedmont (United States)|Piedmont]], and lower mountain regions. southern pine communities dominated the middle and lower Coastal Plains, whereas evergreens and some remnant boreal elements occupied higher elevation sites. There were few canopy openings in the mixed hardwood and high-elevation forest.<ref name=Owen2002 />
Warming and drying during the [[Holocene climatic optimum]] began about 9,000 years ago and affected the vegetation of the Southeast. Extensive expansions of prairies and savannas occurred throughout the region, and xeric oak and oak-hickory forest types proliferated. Cooler-climate species migrated northward and upward in elevation; many vanished from the region during this period while others were limited to isolated refuges. This retreat caused a proportional increase in pine-dominated forests in the Appalachians. The grasslands and savannas of the time expanded and were also linked to the great interior plains grasslands to the west of the region. As a result, elements of the prairie flora became established throughout the region, first by simple migration, but then also by invading disjunct openings (including glades and barrens) that were forming in the canopy of more mesic forests.<ref name=Owen2002 />
During most of the climatic shifts of the last 100,000 years, most plant migration in Eastern North America occurred along a more or less north-south axis. The climate optimum was significant because it made conditions favorable for the invasion and establishment of species from the center of the continent.<ref name=Owen2002 />
After the end of the optimum about 5,000 years BP, as the climate cooled and precipitation increased, species migrated so that communities were reassembled in new forms in which all of the components of the modern southern forests were in place. The boreal forests of the early [[Quaternary]] enjoyed a modest expansion. Riparian, bottomland, and wetland plant communities expanded. Grasslands and savannas contracted and retracted westward.<ref name=Owen2002 />
[[File:Prescribed fire GWJNF Steven Q Croy USDAFS 1995.jpg|thumb|Prescribed fire in Virginia, 1995. Many eastern ridgetops were burned by American Indians.]] At about 4,000 years BP, the [[Archaic period in the Americas|Archaic]] Indian cultures began practicing agriculture throughout the region. Technology had advanced to the point that pottery was becoming common, and the small-scale felling of trees became feasible. Concurrently, the Archaic Indians began using fire in a widespread manner in large portions of the region. Intentional burning of vegetation was taken up to mimic the effects of natural fires that tended to clear forest understories, thereby making travel easier and facilitating the growth of herbs and berry-producing plants that were important for both food and medicines.<ref name=Owen2002 />
{{cquote|For reasons that are unclear, approximately 500 years ago, aboriginal populations declined significantly throughout Eastern North America and more broadly throughout the Americas. … Thus, by the time the first European observers were reporting the nature of the vegetation of the region, it is likely to have changed significantly since the regional peak of Indian influence.
A myth has developed that prior to European culture the New World was a pristine wilderness. In fact, the vegetation conditions that the European settlers observed were changing rapidly because of aboriginal depopulation. As a result, canopy closure and forest tree density were increasing throughout the region.<ref name=Owen2002 />}}
== Recent history ==
[[File:Georgia Anonymous Map of 1779.gif|thumb|Pine savanna (pine land) extended to the Atlantic plain (1779 map).]] The oak-hickory forest of the Northeast was primarily burned by Native Americans, resulting in "oak openings", "barrens", and prairies in the Northeast and the [[Piedmont (United States)|Piedmont]] of North Carolina. There was nearly annual burning throughout the Northeast.<ref name=thompson1971>{{cite journal|last=Thompson|first=Daniel Q.|author2=Ralph H. Smith|year=1971|title=The Forest Primeval in the Northeast - A Great Myth?|journal=Proceedings Annual Tall Timbers Fire Ecology Conference|publisher=Tall Timbers Research Station|location=Tallahassee, Florida|volume=10|page=260}}</ref> After the death of 90% of the native population around 500 years ago, grasslands, savanna, and woodlands succeeded to closed forest. After European settlement of the region the burning frequency was 2–10 years, with many sites burned annually.<ref name=Brown2000 /><ref name=Owen2002 /><ref name=thompson1971 /> The practice was so common that a North Carolina law in the early 18th century required annual burning of pastures and rangelands every March.<ref name=Brown2000 />
In the southeast, [[longleaf pine]] dominated the savanna and open-floored forests which once covered {{convert|92000000|acre|km2}} from Virginia to Texas. These covered 36% of the region's land and 52% of the upland areas. Of this, less than 1% of the unaltered forest still stands.<ref name=PIF2001>{{cite web |url=http://www.blm.gov/wildlife/plan/pl_03_10.pdf |title=Partners in Flight Bird Conservation Plan for The South Atlantic Coastal Plain (Physiographic Area 03) |last=Hunter |first=William C. |author2=Lori H. Peoples |author3=Jaime A. Collazo |date=May 2001 |pages=10–12, 63–64 |accessdate=2008-07-20 |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080517114506/http://www.blm.gov/wildlife/plan/pl_03_10.pdf |archivedate=2008-05-17 |df= }}</ref>
Savannas typically contained grasses that were {{Convert|3–6|feet|4=0}} high.<ref name=Brown2000 />
The southeast also had the [[Black Belt (U.S. region)|Black Belt]] prairie region, within which was the [[blackland prairie]], a type of [[tallgrass prairie]].<ref name=PIF2001 /> Much of the Black Belt region was open space. As late as the 1830s, about 11% of the Black Belt region was covered with prairies.<ref name="Barone2005">{{cite journal|last= Barone|first=John A.|date=2005-09-20|title=Historical Presence and Distribution of Prairies in the Black Belt of Mississippi and Alabama|journal=Castanea|publisher=Southern Appalachian Botanical Society|volume=70|issue=3|pages=170–183|issn=0008-7475|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa4060/is_200509/ai_n15666103/pg_1|accessdate=2008-07-20|doi=10.2179/04-25.1}}</ref>
The largest prairie area in the southern [[Atlantic coastal plain]] was in the Florida panhandle region, from the [[Ochlockonee River]] to Louisiana's [[Florida Parishes]]<ref name=PIF2001 />
{{clear}}
== Savanna elimination ==
The English colonists harvested the longleaf pine lumber, finding many uses for it. The slow-maturing tall straight trees were particularly suitable for shipbuilding and masts, although the lumber and pitch were widely used. The keel of {{USS|Constitution}} was made from a single longleaf pine log. [[George II of Great Britain|King George II]] decreed that straight pines over {{convert|24|in|mm}} in diameter were the king's property, but the colonists protested by tarring and feathering the official surveyors. However, harvesting was rather limited until 1900.<ref name=GOBER>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.state.al.us/publication/TF_publications/tffall99/products_of_the_longleaf_pine.pdf |title=Products of the Longleaf Pine |last=GOBER |first=JIM R. |accessdate=2008-07-20 |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061007170731/http://www.forestry.state.al.us/publication/TF_publications/tffall99/products_of_the_longleaf_pine.pdf |archivedate=October 7, 2006 }}</ref>
At the start of the 20th century, heavy cutover of the southern pine forest, combined with longleaf pine seedling destruction by foraging livestock, eliminated pine regeneration.<ref name=Brown2000 /><ref name=GOBER /> As reflected by the 1924 federal [[Clarke–McNary Act]], fire suppression began to be practiced. The [[American Forestry Association]]'s "Dixie Crusaders" told the South that burning woods were bad.<ref name=Brown2000 /><ref>{{cite book|last=Biswell|first=Harold|author2=James Agee|title=Prescribed Burning in California Wildlands Vegetation Management |publisher=University of California Press|year=1999|page=86|isbn=0-520-21945-7}}</ref> The paper industry encouraged growth of loblolly and slash pines. The probability of catastrophic high-intensity fire increased as dead fuels increased on the forest floor. Overgrowth shades and stunts longleaf pine seedlings, undergrowth increases, and succession creates the southern mixed hardwood forest where savanna used to be. Intentional use of fire to manage vegetation began to be accepted again after World War II, and at present about {{convert|6000000|acre|km2}} a year are burned.<ref name=Brown2000 />
== Remaining examples ==
The ecosystem of over 98% of eastern savanna areas such as longleaf pine have declined.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://biology.usgs.gov/pubs/ecosys.htm|title=Endangered Ecosystems of the United States: A Preliminary Assessment of Loss and Degradation|last1=Noss|first1=Reed F.|author2=Edward T. LaRoe III|author3=J. Michael Scott|accessdate=2008-07-21|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509155011/http://biology.usgs.gov/pubs/ecosys.htm|archive-date=2008-05-09|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
Remaining savanna and prairie cover some of the land in the following locations: * [[Apalachicola National Forest]], Florida<ref name=PIF2001 /> * [[Yellow River Marsh|Garcon Point]], Florida<ref name=PIF2001 /> * [[Kissimmee Prairie Preserve State Park]], Florida<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.floridastateparks.org/park/Kissimmee-Prairie|title=Florida State Parks|website=www.floridastateparks.org|language=en|access-date=2018-05-16}}</ref> * [[Paynes Prairie Preserve State Park]], Florida<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.floridastateparks.org/park/Paynes-Prairie|title=Florida State Parks|website=www.floridastateparks.org|language=en|access-date=2018-05-16}}</ref> * [[Grand Bay National Wildlife Refuge]], Alabama<ref name="PIF2001" /> * Old [[Cahaba, Alabama|Cahawba]] Prairie, Alabama<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.alabamaforeverwild.com/old-cahawba-prairie|title=Old Cahawba Prairie {{!}} Forever Wild|website=www.alabamaforeverwild.com|language=en|access-date=2018-05-16}}</ref> * [[Gautier, Mississippi]]<ref name=PIF2001 /> * [[Harrell Prairie Botanical Area]], Mississippi<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mississippilandcan.org/local-resources/Harrell-Prairie-Hill-Botanical-Area/19639|title=Harrell Prairie Hill Botanical Area - Mississippi Land Conservation Assistance Network|website=Mississippi Land Conservation Assistance Network|language=en|access-date=2018-05-16}}</ref> * [[Okefenokee National Wildlife Refuge]], Georgia<ref name=PIF2001 /> * [[Grand Bay Wetlands Management Area|Grand Bay Wildlife Management Area]], Georgia<ref name=PIF2001 /> * [[Coosa River|Coosa Valley]] Prairies, Georgia<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.myajc.com/lifestyles/environment/tallgrass-prairies-georgia-are-rich-diversity/lf9FXO5AhxqP3xHyk1K6VO/|title=Tallgrass prairies in Georgia are rich in diversity|work=myajc|access-date=2018-05-16|language=en}}</ref> * [[Croatan National Forest]], North Carolina<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.srs.fs.usda.gov/sifg/research/biodiversity/pine-seedling.html|title=Restoration of Longleaf Pine Ecosystems|website=www.srs.fs.usda.gov|access-date=2018-05-16}}</ref> * [[Holly Shelter Swamp|Holly Shelter Game Land]], North Carolina<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.starnewsonline.com/news/20171223/on-map-holly-shelter-game-land-haven-for-outdoor-enthusiasts|title=On the Map: Holly Shelter Game Land a haven for outdoor enthusiasts|last=Staff|first=Ashley Morris StarNews|work=Wilmington Star News|access-date=2018-05-16|language=en}}</ref> * [[Angola Swamp|Angola Bay Game Land]], North Carolina<ref name=":0" /> * [[Green Swamp (North Carolina)|Green Swamp Preserve]], North Carolina<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nature.org/ourinitiatives/regions/northamerica/unitedstates/northcarolina/placesweprotect/green-swamp-preserve.xml|title=Green Swamp Preserve {{!}} The Nature The largest contiguous remaining pine savanna habitat is at *[[Blackwater River State Forest]], Florida, [[Conecuh National Forest]], Alabama, and [[Eglin Air Force Base]], Florida<ref name=PIF2001 />

Growing in the southeast pine forest: * '''Trees''' ** [[Loblolly pine]] (wetter sites)<ref name=Brown2000 /> ** [[Longleaf pine]]<ref name=Brown2000 /><ref name=PIF2001 /> ** [[Pond pine]] (wetter sites)<ref name=Brown2000 /> ** [[Sand pine]] (drier sites)<ref name=Brown2000 /> ** [[Pinus echinata|Shortleaf pine]] (drier sites)<ref name=Brown2000 /> ** [[Slash pine]] (wetter sites)<ref name=Brown2000 /><ref name=PIF2001 /> ** [[Virginia pine]] (drier sites)<ref name=Brown2000 /> * '''Grasses''' ** [[Arundinaria|Cane]] ([[:wikt:cane brake|canebrake]]s along streams)<ref name="Juras1997" /> ** [[Little bluestem]] (central Alabama westward)<ref name=Brown2000 /> ** [[Slender bluestem]] (central Alabama westward)<ref name=Brown2000 /> ** [[Three-awn|Wiregrass]] (Atlantic seaboard)<ref name=Brown2000 /> * '''Woody understory''' ** [[Gallberry (disambiguation)|Gallberry]]<ref name=Brown2000 /> ** [[Serenoa|Saw palmetto]]<ref name=Brown2000 /> ** [[Myrica cerifera|Wax myrtle]]<ref name=Brown2000 />
Exotics promoted by fire: * [[Imperata cylindrica|Cogongrass]]<ref name=Brown2000 /> * [[Lygodium japonicum|Japanese climbing fern]]<ref name=Brown2000 /> * [[Melaleuca quinquenervia|Broad-leaved paper bark]]<ref name=Brown2000 />
== Fauna == [[File:Extermination of bison to 1889.svg|500px|thumb|The range of the American bison included eastern savanna, probably into Florida.<ref name="Rostlund1960" />]] Fauna which lived in the southeastern savanna include: * [[Plains bison]] (circa 1550-1880)<ref name="Juras1997" /><ref name="Rostlund1960">{{cite journal|last=Rostlund|first=Erhard|year=1960|title=The Geographic Range of the Historic Bison in the Southeast|journal=Annals of the Association of American Geographers|publisher=Taylor & Francis, Ltd.|volume=50|issue=4|pages=395–407|jstor=2561275|doi=10.1111/j.1467-8306.1960.tb00357.x}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lib.ncsu.edu/theses/available/etd-19981105-104105/unrestricted/etd.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070330140411/http://www.lib.ncsu.edu/theses/available/etd-19981105-104105/unrestricted/etd.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2007-03-30|title=Using Botanical Analysis to Shape a Longleaf Restoration Project|last=Parker|first=Douglas Seabrook|page=83|accessdate=2008-07-21|format=PDF}}</ref> * [[Bachman's sparrow]]<ref name=PIF2001 /> * [[Brown-headed cowbird]]<ref name=PIF2001 /> * [[Brown-headed nuthatch]]<ref name=PIF2001 /> * [[Fox squirrel|Southeastern fox squirrel]] (''Sciurus niger niger'')<ref name=PIF2001 /> * [[White-tailed deer]]<ref name="Juras1997" /> * [[Elk]]<ref name="Juras1997" /> * [[Flatwoods salamander (disambiguation)|Flatwoods salamanders]]<ref name=PIF2001 /> * [[Gopher frog]]<ref name=PIF2001 /> * [[Gopherus polyphemus|Gopher tortoise]]<ref name=PIF2001 /> * [[Henslow's sparrow]] (winter only)<ref name=PIF2001 /> * [[Drymarchon|Indigo snake]]<ref name=PIF2001 /> * [[Loggerhead shrike]]<ref name=PIF2001 /> * [[Northern bobwhite]]<ref name=PIF2001 /> * [[Prairie warbler|Northern prairie warbler]] (''Setophaga discolor discolor'') - neotropical migrant<ref name=PIF2001 /> * [[Red-cockaded woodpecker]]<ref name=PIF2001 /> * [[American kestrel|Southeastern American kestrel]] (''Falco sparverius paulus'')<ref name=PIF2001 /> * [[Red wolf]]<ref name="Juras1997" /> * [[American black bear]]<ref name="Juras1997" /> * [[North American cougar]]<ref name="Juras1997" />
Living in prairie habitats: * [[Eastern meadowlark]]<ref name=PIF2001 /> * [[Sandhill crane|Florida sandhill crane]] (''Grus canadensis pratensis'')<ref name=PIF2001 /> * [[Savannah sparrow]]<ref name=PIF2001 />

{{Infobox musical composition | name = En vänlig grönskas rika dräkt | type = [[Christian hymn]] | composer = [[Carl David af Wirsén]] | image = | alt = | caption = | translation = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | key = | catalogue = | genre = | form = | text = | language = Swedish | melody = | composed = 1889 | performed = | published = | movements = | scoring = | misc = }} {{italic title}} '''''"En vänlig grönskas rika dräkt..."''''' ("A Friendly Green Does Richly Dress..."), also called '''Sommarpsalm''' ("Summer Hymn"), is a popular 1889 Swedish summer [[hymn]] by the civil servant [[Carl David af Wirsén]], and his only well-known work.
==Summer hymn== [[File:Royal Wedding Stockholm 2010-Slottsbacken-07 edit.jpg|thumb|upright=0.6|The summer hymn was sung for the Swedish royal wedding in June 2010.]]
''En vänlig grönskas rika dräkt'' is one of Sweden's best loved summer hymns, whether sung in unison or in parts.<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JCos-vDQrvEC&pg=PA252 | title=Strong Experiences with Music | publisher=Oxford University Press | date=2011 | accessdate=May 22, 2012 | author=Gabrielsson, Alf. Translated by Rod Bradbury| page=252}}</ref> For example, [[Crown Princess Victoria of Sweden]] chose the hymn for her [[Wedding of Victoria, Crown Princess of Sweden, and Daniel Westling|wedding]] to Daniel Westling in June 2010.<ref name=SN>{{cite web | url=http://www.stockholmnews.com/more.aspx?NID=5503 | title=Stockholm News | work=Crown Princess Couple married | date=19 June 2010 | accessdate=21 May 2012 | author=Jonasson, David}}</ref> In 2002 the hymn reached the Swedish pop music charts in a recording by [[The Real Group]] on the 2002 album ''{{ill|Stämning|sv|Stämning (album)}}'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://smdb.kb.se/catalog/id/001553642|title=Stämning|publisher=Svensk mediedatabas|language=Swedish|date=2002|accessdate=4 September 2016}}</ref> scoring a [[Svensktoppen]] hit for six weeks between 15 June and 13 July 2002.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sverigesradio.se/p4/svetop/2002/020615sv.htm|title=Svensktoppen 15 juni 2002|publisher=Sveriges radio|language=Swedish|date=15 June 2002|accessdate=4 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://sverigesradio.se/p4/svetop/2002/020720sv.htm|title=Svensktoppen 20 juli 2002|publisher=Sveriges radio|language=Swedish|date=20 July 2002|accessdate=4 September 2016}}</ref>
The first Swedish hymnbook to include the hymn was ''{{ill|Nya psalmer 1921|sv}}'', where it was number 644. The melody was composed by S. Gastorius in 1675.<ref>'' Koralbok till Nya psalmer, av konungen medgivna att användas tillsammans med 1819 års psalmbok.'' Nordisk Nodestik- og Tryckkeri, Copenhagen, 1921.</ref> The melody used in most later hymnbooks is from a 1933 choral composition by Waldemar Åhlén (1894–1982).<ref>[http://www.realgroup.se/attachments/098_stamning_alla_texter.pdf ''En vänlig grönskas rika dräkt'' (Sommarpsalm)(#201)]. Retrieved 22 May 2012.</ref><ref>[http://evl.fi/psalmbok.nsf/nr/539?OpenDocument Evangelisk-lutherska kyrkan i Finland: Psalmbok (1986)]. (All five verses) Retrieved 22 May 2012.</ref>
In 2016-2017 the melody was used in a [[Länsförsäkringar]] TV commercial film.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://markbladet.se/?artikel=201704260827371816|title=Varför psalmen?|publisher=Markbladet|language=Swedish|date=26 April 2017|accessdate=17 December 2017}}</ref>
==Reception==
Cordelia Edvardson, writing in ''[[Svenska Dagbladet]]'', identifies the hymn as a beloved example of popular poetry, part of the Swedish people's cultural heritage. So for example, she writes, in verse two "the dizzy birds" (''de yra fåglarna'') express the joy of summertime.<ref name=SvD>{{cite web | url=http://www.svd.se/nyheter/inrikes/berova-inte-svenska-folket-deras-kulturarv_1463981.svd | title=Svenska Dagbladet: Nyheter | work=Beröva inte svenska folket deras kulturarv | date=16 July 2008 | accessdate=21 May 2012 | author=Edvardson, Cordelia}}</ref>
Carlhåkan Larsén, reviewing Per Rydén's book about Carl David af Wirsén in ''[[Sydsvenskan]]'', describes Wirsén as a loser on the dark side of literary history, only one of whose poems still survives: the summer hymn, ''En vänlig grönskas rika dräkt''.<ref name=SydSv>{{cite web|url=https://www.sydsvenskan.se/2010-06-08/allt-om-en-loser |title=Sydsvenskan: Kultur & Nöjen |work=Allt om en loser |date=8 June 2010 |accessdate=21 May 2012 |author=Larsén, Carlhåkan }}</ref>
Hans Holmberg, writing in ''[[Kristianstadsbladet]]'', notes that the hymn is part of Sweden's summer repertoire, and that people usually sing "only the first three verses, which are a hymn of praise to summer."<ref name=Kristianstadsbladet>{{cite web | url=http://www.kristianstadsbladet.se/kultur/article851675/Fraringn-lovsaringng-till-foumlrgaumlngelse.html | title=Kristianstadsbladet: Kultur | work=Från lovsång till förgängelse | date=5 July 2010 | origyear=2004| accessdate=21 May 2012 | author=Holmberg, Hans}}</ref> But, observes Holmberg, the remaining verses are quite different: they give a feeling of decay, with the biblical phrase "[[All flesh is grass]]". The hymn, writes Holmberg, switches repeatedly between life and praise on the one hand, and death and decay on the other. ''En vänlig grönskas rika dräkt'' can be and is used both as a summer hymn and for funerals: but, remarks Holmberg, "I find it hard to imagine an occasion when the hymn is sung in its entirety".<ref name=Kristianstadsbladet/> In fact, Holmberg concludes, while Wirsén is now derided as a dusty permanent secretary to the [[Swedish Academy]], he was actually too bold for us to follow nowadays.<ref name=Kristianstadsbladet/>
==Publication history==
* ''{{ill|Hemlandssånger 1892|sv}}'' as no. 408 under heading ''Kärleken'' (Love) with melodies by Georg Stolpe and August Elfåker, neither of which are used in the Swedish hymnal. * ''{{ill|Nya psalmer 1921|sv}}'' as no. 644 under headings ''Tidens skiften: Årets tider: Sommaren'' (Changing times: Seasons: Summer). * ''{{ill|1937 års psalmbok|sv}}'' as no. 476 under heading ''Sommaren'' (Summer). * ''{{ill|Cantarellen 1984|sv}}'' as no. 23. * ''{{ill|1986 års psalmbok|sv}}'' as no. 201 (copied into several other hymnals). * ''{{ill|Lova Herren 1988|sv}}'' as no. 789 under heading ''Årets tider'' (Seasons). * ''{{ill|Sångboken 1998|sv}}'' as no. 22.
